Strengthening Health Security in the People's 
Republic of China Project

I.  THE ENSUING PROJECT 
 
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  China  (PRC),  through  the  National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC), has requested the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) for support to prepare the proposed Strengthening Health Security Project. The proposed 
transaction technical assistance (TA) and the ensuing loan are ADB’s response to addressing the 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic.  
 
2.   Emerging infectious diseases (EIDs) continue to be a significant public health concern 
and  cause  of  considerable  socioeconomic  disruption  in the  PRC. Most  of  these  EIDs  are 
zoonoses—diseases  that  originate  from  animals.  Approximately  60%  of  all  known  human 
infectious diseases in the world and about 75% of EIDs affecting people are zoonotic.1 EIDs are 
particularly important because of its complex and uncertain nature with an impact that transcends 
the health sector. The experiences highlighted by the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) 
in 2003 and the COVID-19, both of which are EIDs, demonstrate immediate consequences on 
health, travel restrictions, social distancing, stringent community quarantine measures, among 
others. The tremendous effect is equally magnified in the economy, with the slowing down of trade 
and supply chains, businesses, travel, consumer spending, and overall economic activity. COVID-
19 is expected to have serious impact on poverty and welfare, through illness, death, and lost 
incomes.2 Economic forecast notes that continued COVID-19 outbreak would cost the PRC as 
much as $692 billion in economic losses.3     
 
3.  The unprecedented impact of COVID-19 outbreak has led to the PRC’s renewed interest 
on the development of focused preparedness and response programs for longer-term health 
security. The regional and global public goods nature of health, prevention, and control of EIDs is 
clear, and fundamentally an issue of international security and economic development. Preventing 
future outbreaks in EID hotspots such as the PRC is an important investment. Additionally, the 
PRC is at a crucial development phase, and the government requires international support and 
cooperation to balance development and address challenges posed by future outbreaks. The 
project will support the PRC in the development of an integrated system to strengthen the health 
security of the country. The project comprises upgrading of public health emergency facilities; 
development of modernized disease prevention, policies, research, and control systems; and 
improvement of talent building and international exchange capabilities. 
 
4.  Output 1: Public health emergency facilities upgraded. The project will address gaps 
in core capacities in health systems to withstand huge demand for critical care as well as maintain 
essential health services in times of epidemics and other public health emergencies. The project 
will facilitate the (i) development of national standards for the renovation and refurbishment work 
for health facilities, (ii) site inspection of select public health facilities directly targeted under the 
project, (iii) actual renovation work in targeted public health facilities, and (iv) procurement of 
medical and laboratory equipment and diagnostics supplies.  The project will (i) strengthen 
infection prevention and control capacities in health care settings; (ii) improve referral system to 
mobilize all levels of health care during epidemics; and (iii) pilot innovative technology solutions 
to facilitate disease prevention, detection, and response.   
 
 
1  K.E. Jones et al. 2008. Global Trends in Emerging Infectious Diseases. 
https://www.nature.com/articles/nature06536. 
2   World Bank Group. World Bank East Asia and Pacific Economic Update, April 2020: East Asia and Pacific in the 
Time of COVID-19. 
3   ADB. Asian Development Outlook 2020: What Drives Innovation in Asia?

2 
5.  Output 2: Modernized disease prevention policies, research, and control systems 
developed. The project will strengthen institutional capacity for disease prevention and control 
systems to ensure strategies and resources needed are in place to address infectious disease 
outbreaks and other public health emergencies. The project will focus on the advancement of 
policies, standards, and guidelines; development of comprehensive prevention, control, and 
response  plans;  provision  of  equipment;  development  of  governance  and  coordination 
mechanisms with other sectors; and collaborative research and knowledge sharing. The project 
will (i) enhance preparedness plans including continuity of essential services, risk communication 
and community engagement, and emergency response including surge staff deployment and 
procurement of essential supplies; (ii) build disease surveillance and response system to quickly 
identify EID networks and facilitate arrangements with international reference laboratories, and 
develop standard operating procedures; (iii) develop a national interoperable electronic reporting 
system to facilitate timely reporting and quick response; (iv) establish collaboration mechanism 
with relevant stakeholders including non-health ministries, specialized agencies, private sector 
organizations, and civil society; (v) establish collaborative research programs with academics and 
specialized  agencies,  and  undertake  research on  key topics;  and  (vi)  enhance  knowledge 
management and use of existing knowledge platforms to share scientific researches and good 
practices. The project will explore system elements that have important functions in the wider 
health sector, such as equitable access to health care services and long-term health needs of key 
population groups that can be considered for future investments. 
 
6.  Output 3: Training excellence and international cooperation capability enhanced. 
The project will support the development of (i) capacity building training for public health staff 
including certificate courses on key topics (e.g., One Health approach,4 disease modeling, 
complex  data  analysis,  analytical  techniques  to  locate  areas  at  highest  risk,  outbreak 
preparedness  and management,  laboratory  diagnosis  of  EIDs,  and  laboratory  and  medical 
logistics  management);  and  (ii)  international  exchange  programs.  The  project  will  facilitate 
partnership with academe and specialized agencies in strengthening public health professional 
education and setting quality standards. The project will establish a regional cooperation platform 
to host regular technical forums and continuing education and this can be linked with existing 
regional platforms such as the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Program and 
Greater Mekong Subregion Economic Cooperation Program. 
 
7.  Strategic fit. The project is aligned with ADB’s strategic operational priority on addressing 
remaining poverty and reducing inequalities, in particular the recognition of Asian economies 
vulnerabilities to health security threats.5 The project is consistent with the Greater Mekong 
Subregion health cooperation, which include Yunnan Province and Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous 
Region, PRC, committing to multisector cooperation through One Health approach.6 
 
8.  ADB value added. ADB has been working with the PRC since 1986, with a rich history of 
development finance and knowledge sharing. ADB is committed to working with the PRC in 
addressing development challenges and implementing national priorities and support the PRC in 
areas where it can add most value. The project is an opportunity to demonstrate an approach to 
strengthen capacity of the country to effectively respond to emerging diseases, improve health, 
and facilitate economic development. ADB can specifically contribute to the progressive adoption 
of broader policy agenda on health security, initiate innovative and appropriate solutions to tackle 
 
4  The World Health Organization defines One Health approach to designing and implementing programs, policies, and 
research in which multiple sectors work together to achieve better public health outcomes. One Health is particularly 
relevant to the control of diseases that can spread between animals and humans. 
5  ADB. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
6  ADB. Greater Mekong Subregion Health Cooperation Strategy 2019–2023.

3 
emerging infections, enable accessibility of specialized agencies and individual national and 
international experts, and strengthen common approaches to EID threats of international concern 
aligned with the Healthy China 2030 plan.7 
 
9.  The project will result in the following outcome: management of epidemics of infectious 
diseases and other health hazards improved. The project will be aligned with the following 
impacts: capacity for early warning, risk reduction, and management of national health risks 
strengthened;8 and prevention and control of major communicable diseases strengthened.9 The 
modality is a regular loan of $300 million to be financed from ADB's ordinary capital resources.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
10.  The NDRC, the executing agency, has limited experience with ADB requirements in the 
development and processing of projects on health. The transaction TA will support the NDRC to 
prepare the ensuing project in accordance with country needs and ADB requirements, and 
consistent with international good practices.10 The TA will undertake the relevant tasks and due 
diligence for assessing the technical, financial, and economic viability of the project, and the social 
and environmental impacts of the project.  
 
B.  Outputs and Activities 
 
11.  The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1.

C.  Cost and Financing 
 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $1.5 million, of which $1.3 million will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF) resources special pool for COVID-19 
response. The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff; office 
accommodation; domestic transportation; data collection; logistics support for training, workshops, 
and consultations; and other in-kind contributions. The government was informed that approval 
of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
14.  ADB will administer the TA. Activities will be carried out in close coordination with NDRC. 
A project steering committee, chaired by the NDRC and comprising representatives from key 
government  agencies,  will  provide  guidance  to  the  TA  and  the  ensuing  project.  A  project 
management  office  will  be  established  at  the  NDRC  to  coordinate  project  activities  and 
corresponding project implementation units in project areas to oversee project implementation.

5

16.  Consulting services. ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement 
Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated procurement staff instructions.11  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,300,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People's Republic of China for Preparing the Strengthening Health 
Security in the People's Republic of China Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.
 
11 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).
